TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant brought a civil action , claiming back the money which she had lent to a private person on DATE , further to a note envisaging repayment within DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the respondent replied in writing , claiming that she had repaid the debt and that the applicant 's action was time - barred under Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ( “ the ORG ” ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE FAC allowed the applicant 's claim at an oral hearing . The court found that the respondent 's assertion about payment of the debt was unsubstantiated . It did not reply to the time - bar objection .

CARDINAL . On DATE the respondent appealed , reiterating , inter alia , that the applicant 's action was time - barred . The latter replied that , in view of the respondent 's continuous promises to discharge the debt , she could not have concluded that her rights had been breached DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and decided the case anew , dismissing the applicant 's action as time - barred . The appellate court found that the limitation period had started to run from the date of non - compliance with the note of DATE , that is DATE after the loan , on DATE . It noted that the case materials did not substantiate the applicant 's assertion that the respondent had continuously promised to return the money .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a cassation claim . Referring to varioushe reiterated that the respondent 's verbal assurances had prevented her from applying to the court earlier . She consequently claimed that the appellate court had wrongly applied Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE declared the applicant 's cassation claim admissible but decided to dispense with an oral hearing on the merits . Both parties were informed of that decision on DATE . On DATE , the cassation claim was forwarded to the respondent for comments . No reply was forthcoming from the latter .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's cassation claim . Endorsing the facts of the case as established by the appellate court , the cassation court found that the disputed Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the ORG had been correctly interpreted and applied in the appellate judgment of DATE and that , consequently , there was no ground , under LAW and CARDINAL of LAW , to quash it .

Pursuant to Articles CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL , the period for bringing contractual claims was limited to DATE , and it started to run from the moment the person learnt or should have learnt about the breach of his or her rights .

Pursuant to LAW , only the lawfulness of an appellate judgment could be challenged in cassation . The disputed judgment could be found to be unlawful if the appellate court had wrongly applied or interpreted the law .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( f ) required the appellant to mention in his or her cassation claim those facts which supported the alleged breaches of procedural law if the cassation claim was calling into question the application of procedural legal provisions .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL

“ The cassation court shall review the [ disputed ] judgment only in so far as challenged in the cassation claim . The cassation court can not go beyond the facts referred to under LAW ( f ) and inquire of its own motion into other procedural breaches . ”

“ The cassation court shall take into account the party 's submissions only in so far as disclosed by the case file or the appellate judgment ; only the facts submitted under LAW ( f ) can be taken into account .
The establishment of the facts [ by the appellate court ] is binding on the [ cassation ] court , unless an additional and well - founded cassation argument has been raised . ”
“ In the event the cassation court finds it appropriate ... , it can decide the case without an oral hearing . The parties shall be notified of such a decision . ”
Article CARDINAL
“ The cassation court shall take a [ final ] decision
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL and CARDINAL
“ If it is not possible for the cassation court to decide the case in accordance with LAW , it shall quash the appellate judgment and remit the case for a retrial .
ORG dismissed the applicants ' complaint challenging LAW of the ORG , which provided for the possibility to dispense with an oral hearing in cassation proceedings .

ORG noted that , unlike an appellate court which established facts , the cassation court could only review the application of legal provisions . It could however examine , on the basis of ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( f ) and QUANTITY of the ORG , the facts which have been explicitly raised by the appellant in relation to the alleged violations of procedural law .

Consequently , whilst the scope of the review was mostly limited to the assessment of the application of procedural and substantive law , ORG concluded that the right to an oral hearing in cassation proceedings was not absolute .
In its judgment of DATE in the case of “ NORP ” v. “ NORP ” ORG , ORG defined the notion of an “ additional and well - founded cassation argument ” ( LAW ORG ) , as follows :

“ ... ' An additional and well - founded cassation argument ' is ... a reference to those procedural breaches which , having been committed by the appellate court during the examination of the case , have resulted in an erroneous assessment of the matters of fact and/or the incorrect interpretation and application of substantive legal provisions . ”
